title: 109_hr3148
content: The Act may be cited as the "Joint Administrative Procedures Committee Act of 2005" or the "JACP Act" and establishes a Joint Administrative Procedures Committee. Section 802 of title 5, United States Code, is amended to establish a Joint Administrative Procedures Committee composed of 12 Members of the Senate and 12 Members of the House of Representatives, with a limit of 7 members from the same political party. The committee is authorized to hold hearings, require witness attendance, and act during Congress sessions, recesses, and adjourned periods. The Joint Administrative Procedures Committee, established under Section 802 of title 5, United States Code, has the authority to hold hearings, require witness attendance, administer oaths, and review existing major rules of Federal agencies. It can recommend legislative actions to amend or repeal laws and suggest amendments or repeals to major rules. The committee also periodically reviews the regulatory plans of Federal agencies. The Joint Administrative Procedures Committee has the authority to review regulatory plans of Federal agencies and may selectively review existing rules that meet specific criteria. The committee can recommend legislative actions regarding major rules and hold hearings to gather information. The Joint Administrative Procedures Committee has the authority to review regulatory plans of Federal agencies and recommend legislative actions to amend or repeal laws. Members of the committee report their recommendations to the appropriate standing committees of the Senate and House of Representatives. The Joint Administrative Procedures Committee has the authority to review regulatory plans of Federal agencies and recommend legislative actions. Vacancies in the joint committee do not affect its functions, and members select a chairman and vice chairman at the start of each Congress. The chairmanship alternates between the Senate and the House of Representatives, with the vice chairman chosen from the opposite House. The joint committee may appoint and determine compensation. The joint committee has the authority to appoint staff and set their compensation. Expenses of the joint committee are split between the House of Representatives and the Senate, with payments made by the chairman or vice chairman of the joint committee. Amounts allocated must be spent according to House of Representatives regulations. SEC. 3. CONSIDERATION IN THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES AND THE SENATE. Section 802 of title 5, United States Code, is amended to allow any Member of the House to move to proceed to consideration of a joint resolution after the committee has reported. The motion is privileged, not debatable, and not subject to amendment. If agreed to, the House shall immediately proceed. The House shall immediately proceed to consideration of the joint resolution without intervening motion, order, or other business. Debate shall be confined to the joint resolution and shall not exceed one hour equally divided and controlled by a proponent and an opponent. The previous question shall be considered as ordered on the joint resolution to final passage without intervening motion, except one motion to recommit. SEC. 4. CONGRESSIONAL REVIEW. Section 801(a) of title 5, United States Code is amended to include provisions for the joint committee to report a committee resolution recommending disapproval of applicable rules within 30 days of receiving the report. The text chunk discusses amendments to sections of title 5, United States Code related to the joint committee's role in reporting recommendations for disapproval of rules. It also adds a definition for the term 'joint committee' as the Joint Administrative Procedures Committee.
